data.title: put_pixel( region, data ) available on video memory (feature request)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I'm using pixel per pixel calculations and texture modifications at runtime. 
At the moment Godot does not allow pixel/region texture updates on video memory. You can only update entire texture in video memory at once. 
Before switching  to Godot I was doing this in C++/ OpenGL. Where entire environment was destroyable pixel per pixel. Doing the same in Godot is possible only to certain texture size, after that performance happens.
This kind of problem requires you to keep a copy of the textures in Ram and update any changes to Vram.
This can look like this: 
```
data = self.get_texture().get_data()
imageTexture = ImageTexture.new()
imageTexture.create(width, height, self.get_texture().get_format(), 0)    
imageTexture.set_data(data)
data.put_pixel( position.x, position.y, Color(1,0,0,1), 0 )
imageTexture.set_data(data)
```
If you need to run following code every 5-20 frames it becomes problematic.  
```
data.put_pixel( position.x, position.y, Color(1,0,0,1), 0 )
imageTexture.set_data(data)
```
It is possible to update texture once per second or so, but if the textures are 2048x2048 then it is still a bottleneck.

Being able to call functions like the ones defined for Image class, but straight on video memory would allow new possibilities for the engine. 
Especially:
```
blit_rect ( Image src, Rect2 src_rect, Vector2 dest=0 )
Color 	get_pixel ( int x, int y, int mipmap_level=0 )
Image 	get_rect ( Rect2 area=0 )
void 	put_pixel ( int x, int y, Color color, int mipmap_level=0 )
```
I was wondering how difficult would it be to add this feature?

data.title: ScrollBar in ScrollContainer is not updated when child is resized
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.2 alpha with current master head

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
ScrollBar in ScrollContainer is not updated when child is resized until scroll event is occurred.

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
ScrollContainer
    - GridContainer
        - children nodes
```
GridContainer will resize if children nodes is removed.
But ScrollBars of ScrollContainer is not updated.


**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Lock icons are not affected by CanvasLayer
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1 and 2.1.1, Windows 10, 64 bits

Repro:
1) Create a CanvasLayer and set its scale to (3, 3)
2) Create a Sprite as child of CanvasLayer, with a texture on it
3) Move the sprite off the origin, then lock it
4) Observe the lock icon is off, as if it was not affected by the scale.

I expected the lock icon to be shown on the sprite as usual, but its size and rotation should not be affected (just like the rectangular handles of the sprite).

Example project:
[LocksAndCanvasLayers.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/598933/LocksAndCanvasLayers.zip)

data.title: ScrollContainer or GraphEdit.get_children() returns unexpected child nodes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.2 alpha with current master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
ScrollContainer.get_children() returns also it's sub component like HScrollBar and VScrollBar.
I expected just it's children shown as in nodes Scene tree of editor.
This can cause crash if remove all children of ScrollContainer.

```gdscript
for node in scroll_container.get_children():
    node.queue_free()
```

```gdscript
for node in graph_edit.get_children():
    node.queue_free()
```

data.body:
This PR includes the 2 main IPv6 patches (#6925 and  #6981) plus a small fix for the windows build script to include the proper socket library.

I managed to get a build for Windows, Linux, and OSX. So far so good.

data.title: Script Editor drawing over Script Save Dialog
data.body:
Windows 10 Home 64-Bits
Godot version: 2.1.1 Stable 32-bits

While editing an unsaved script if you have a function tooltip showing and try to save it the script editor is rendered over the Save Dialog.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add a new script to a node from Inspector
2. Type the name of a function that uses arguments without adding any arguments and without closing it with ")"
3. Wait for the tooltip to show
4. _Ctrl+Alt+S_ to try to save it

[**Screenshot**](https://gyazo.com/31d2162beabcbb798e6bc52ff48a2348)

Additional info:
I think it might be related to Andreas Haas "Fix code completion drawing under other gui elements.".
It doesn't happen in 2.1.0 Stable so it's definitely a 2.1.1 bug.

data.title: Feature: Realtime Collaboration
data.body:
It's a huge task to build, but it would be amazing if you could have multiple users edit a single Godot project at once as opposed to using Git.

It would be similar to Google Docs, where any changes made in a project would update instantly across all connected users.

To avoid having to invest in servers for this, the host user could port forward their IP and share it with other users to connect and collaborate.

This can be seen in an engine called Superpowers HTML5.

data.title: Do not enter _ready twice
data.body:
There are two commits in this PR -- the first guards only against a special case of `add_child` inside `_enter_tree`, while the second one guards against all cases.

Because of this, this PR is going to break some projects (and maybe AnimationPlayer/Tween/Joint2D as well, who knows..).
But, the first commit fixes a buggy behavior, so it can (and maybe should) be backported to 2.x.

data.title: Correct description for the return values from get_status.
data.body: Fixes https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/7132.

data.title: Center of mass offset for RigidBody and RigidBody2D.
data.body:
Currently the center of mass is always at the origin point of the RigidBody. There is no way to change the center of mass without moving all of the collision shapes and visual nodes so that the origin is offset.

I would like to have a function to offset the center of mass away from the origin without having to move everything around.

data.title: High Level Networking + TCP punchthrough?
data.body:
When using the high level networking functionality in Godot master, it seems you can either be a client or a server -- not both. However, in order to do NAT punchthrough for TCP, you have to attempt to both send and receive a TCP connection to both peers in order for it to work, and once the TCP connection is lost so is the NAT mapping. Well, that's my understanding of it, anyway. 

Is there a method of using the high level networking component while also enabling punchthrough? If not, will UPnP be supported before G3, since that mostly removes the need for punchthrough techniques?

data.title: Don't default the FileSystem pane to expanding every folder
data.body:
This is a UI/Usability improvement request

In most file explorers (such as Windows Explorer, Mac OS Finder) that have a tree style representation of the directory structure of a file system, they do not default to having every folder expanded.

However godot's FileSystem pane defaults to having every single folder in the file system expanded every time a project is opened. For large projects with complex directory structures, this makes finding a specific folder tedious.

Some people (those with less complex directory structures) may prefer having them all expanded though. Advanced IDEs actually remember the expand/collapse state of their project explorers - which is something that would be a nice improvement to Godot.

data.title: Make better use of right side Inspector empty space / allow resizing values column
data.body:
This is a UI/Usability improvement request.

Right now the Inspector on the right side of the screen which is used to edit scene properties, is making wasteful use of the space available.

For example see this:
![ex1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/357737/20377165/c2c1d740-acbf-11e6-96e2-0ba6912c5a84.png)
There is a lot of space wasted between the word Path and the beginning of the actual path value and there is no way to resize the value column (that I know of). This is a big issue for values that are not numbers (ex. strings, enum style options)

The only way to increase the width of the value column is to increase the width of the whole Inspector which results in this:
![ex2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/357737/20377211/20fb4990-acc0-11e6-95cf-29369794fe9b.png)
Here even though the width has been increased by a lot, the value column is still not wide enough to show the complete Path value. Instead of the value column being given priority / more space, the property names column have been given more, resulting in lots of wasted space.

In order to see the whole value the Inspector needs to be expanded even more:
![ex3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/357737/20377255/7dd2a7ee-acc0-11e6-9847-26f3a571fda7.png)

In the first two images above, it is possible to view the full value by hovering the mouse over it, however it doesn't help when editing the value.

Suggestion is to either:
1. Allow resizing of value column
or
2. Limit width of property names column to the width of the longest property name
and/or
3. Change priority so that more space is given to value column

At least combination of 2 and 3 would go a long way and it would not require implementing additional UI.

data.title: HTTPClient get_status doc description is contradictory.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
All platforms

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The description for HTTPClient.get_status is contradictory. It currently returns an int.
So either this is a doc fix or a code fix. I would rather see a code fix so that get_status() returns a string.

**Steps to reproduce:**

>  **int get_status ( ) const**
> 
> Returns a status string like STATUS_REQUESTING. Need to call poll in order to get status updates.

data.title: Godot tries to open files that do not exist.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
linux x86_64 
branch master

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I am looking at why godot consumes cpu when nothing is really going on.
The joystick monitor runs a loop every 1 sec. and checks for /dev/input/event{0,31} devices.
Checking if they exist will be more lightweight compared to trying to open them.
The gain may not be huge but the change should be simple enough. In the link below a stat() call consumes less than half as much cpu

Godot also tries to open these two files:
/blackberry-deploy
""
The blackberry-deploy attempt should not happen or exist under the root "/" and I don't know why Godot is trying to open a file called ""

**Steps to reproduce:**
Start godot
`strace -fF -e trace=open -p <godot pid>`


**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
FWIW some perf numbers on a different ways to test if a file exists. Note that stat() does the best.
http://stackoverflow.com/a/12774387

data.title: A variable behavior for KinematicBody move
data.body:
Feat. request:

Since most new features will be added on 3.0 and that may include `move_and_slide`, I was thinking on the possibility to have more types of `move`, mostly for prototyping (fine tuning will always fall on pure move).

These are:
-A move that push: something basic to push other colliders, common use on puzzle and some platformers.
-A relative move: use transform to apply the movement, useful for FPS, third person (3D) and topdown (2D) games.

Then I also thought that combinations of slide, push and local moves could be needed and got this final idea:

Have a single `move` and some flags on the KinematicBody that affects the way move behave.

- If no flag is on: move just works like normal move.
- If relative, the movement vector will be rotated according to the body transform.
- If slide is checked, move will also uses extra parameters for sliding (floor normal, slope speed, like `move_and_slide`).
- If push is checked, it will affect the collider (could filter if rigid or kinematic too, like raycast).

I have made a simple project with a basic controller and these options exposed on the inspector to show the idea:

[kinemoves.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/595087/kinemoves.zip)

data.title: IPv6 for Godot 2.1.x
data.body:
The recently-implemented IPv6 support in the master branch seems to behave, at least @punto- reports that some guys were able to publish their iOS game without any trouble (so Apple did not complain about missing support - and I suppose the game worked too :)).

There have been quite a few commits about this, so instead of trying to cherry-pick them myself, I'd like someone who understands this stuff to do it :)

@Faless Would you mind preparing a pull request to the 2.1 branch to add all the IPv6-related commits?

You can cherry-pick with `git cherry-pick -x <commit-hash>` - the `-x` part adds the hash of the original commit to the description of the cherry-picked commit, I'm using this as a convention for better traceability.

data.title: Project Manager - features proposal
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
GODOT 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Project Manager - Project List.
1) The list of projects is not sorted at all, it's hard to find projects there. What about adding sort by: NAME, DATE OF CREATION, DATE OF LAST LAUNCH?

2) Would be cool if project could be organizes into 2-level group hierarchy with custom group names. So user could create groups like:  "demo projects", "my current", "my old", "3rd party games"

3) Import button - would be cool to have a checkbox [X] scan subdirectories, so I could
   add all demo projects with single directory selection

data.title: Core motion implementation for iPhone (Accelerometer/Gyro/Magnetometer support)
data.body:
These changes replace the now deprecated UIAccelerometer implementation with one using the newer CoreMotion, specifically implementing CMDeviceMotion. This adds gyro and magnetometer data to the iPhone platform. 

I've gone for a simple polling approach, CMDeviceMotion does have an option for pushing data but I'm not sure if there is any added benefit.

The accelerometer data is split into a user vector and gravity vector by iOS but I add them together again so it behaves as before.

The gyro seems to work but testing an app that was build for the Android platform the axis seem flipped. Without an Android device to compare output with I'm not entirely sure how to best deal with this. 

I have not been able to test the magnetometer output, my iPhone 5 doesn't seem to be giving any output though that may be a fault on my side in testing.

data.title: Fix memory leak
data.body: fix some memory leak

data.title: X11: Fix maximized boot splash
data.body:
When instructing the window manager to (un-)maximize a window, the resulting resolution
is received via an `XEvent` of type `ConfigureNotify`.

The problem here was that these events were only handled in the `OS_X11::process_xevents()` method,
which is initially called on the first iteration of the main loop.
Because of this, the `VideoMode` still hadn't been updated yet when doing the boot splash setup.

data.title: WebM: Fix iPhone x86 compilation
Fix compilation with MSVC 2013
Stereo camera
data.body:
These changes introduce a new camera mode to the camera object in Godot so it can be set as a uniform left/right/top/bottom frustum. The main reason for this is to allow asymmetrical frustums which is not possible with the normal camera settings but this is needed for left eye / right eye stereoscopic rendering. 

Note that the frustum is defined at unit distance NOT at the near plane. This allows the near and far plane to be adjusted without needing to change the frustum values themselves.
Also keep in mind that Godot will apply the aspect ratio of the viewport you are rendering to, you should not apply the aspect ratio to the frustum yourself (many textbook FOV -> frustum calculations will do this).

To help with this the PR also introduces a few functions on the camera that allow you to set the frustum based on the intraoculur distance (distance between the two eyes) and convergence distance (distance at which they eyes converge, basically anything in front of this will seem to pop out towards you, anything behind this distance will be seen as in depth).

I've got a little test project here:
https://github.com/BastiaanOlij/StereoCameraTest
This shows the stereoscopic rendering of two eyes to a split screen. I'll be adding on to this sample project in due time to highlight some of the differences between rendering for an HMD (if you want to use this for cardboard like mobile solutions) and stereo rendering on a 3D TV.

data.title: iPhone Gyro and Magnetometer support
data.body:
The current iPhone implementation only has accelerometer support and uses an approach marked as deprecated in iOS 7 if I read things correctly on the apple website.

I've made changes to the source code in my own fork and changed the code over to use CMMotionManager and also read out the gyro and magnetometer values. 

So far it just passes them on to Godot as they are with just the z flipped (the original code did so, its just a starting point). I have not yet gotten a chance to see what further adjustments are needed to make the output compatible with Android on which this already works.

I'd change this into a pull request but pretty new to contributing with GIT and I'm not sure how to isolate just these changes from other changes I've made yet. 

Anyway, could use some help finalising these changes and submitting them for further evaluation.

Fix #7127

data.title: Make preload invalid paths null instead of a compilation error
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10
Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description**:
The current behavior of preload with invalid paths is give an error in editor (Can't preload resource at path) and crash at runtime.
![xh5vlyr 1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12376042/20278259/c66f7792-aa82-11e6-862b-9bfe5e13d328.png)
A better approach could be instead of give an error in editor and crash at runtime, preload could return null and let the user check ingame if the preloaded var/const is null.

This could be useful for addons, for example I have an addon which has a timer created by script for delayed triggers and I wan't the trigger addon to be independant from the project, but for this project the timer could be paused with a player ability, so I need a way to attach that script for the timer in the trigger. The easiest and optimal way to achieve this could be preload const and check if the script path is null.  So with this I could use the addon  without major modifications in another project or I could put another timer script at the path for custom behaviour in a new project.

NOTE: I'm aware of load and check/load the path in ready:
```
const _timer_script_path = "res://resources/scripts/timer.gd"

func _ready():
	var timer = Timer.new()
	var script = load(_timer_script_path)
	if(script != null):
		timer .set_script(script)
```
But that method should be less optimal because is 1 load for EACH ready vs a SINGLE preload in a CONST at start of the game

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create a script and try to preload an invalid resource with a const and run the game:
`const _script = preload("res://resources/scripts/timer.gd")`

data.title: No index.html created with `make html` in godot/doc
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux 
X86_64 
github master branch
godot mainline


**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
No index.html created when building html documentation
An index.html should exist according to all the links to it in the other html pages.

**Steps to reproduce:**

`cd godot/doc`
`make html`
`ls -l _build/html/index.html`
`/bin/ls: cannot access '_build/html/index.html': No such file or directory`

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
See above command line steps.
